tossups.question: The studio behind this game commissioned Max Brooks, author of World War Z, to write a novelization of this game subtitled “The Island.” When an Evoker is killed in this game, it drops an item that prevents the player from dying by restoring them to 1 health. Certain items in this game disappear upon death when the Curse of Vanishing is applied to them. An April 2019 update to this game added the (*) “Bad Omen” status effect, which triggers a pillager raid when a player enters villages. Those villages are generated structures in this game where players can trade emeralds for items like ender pearls and redstone. In 2017, Microsoft bought this game for $2.5 billion from Markus Persson, also known as “Notch.” For 10 points, surviving the night against skeletons and mining diamonds are objectives of what Mojang-created block-centric sandbox game?

Red, blue, and black tangram-like shapes pattern a room with black and white bars in an entry titled Gnomus in a series of “Pictures” by this artist. This artist, who was inspired by a performance of Lohengrin, created two “Fragments” that drew upon Old Testament themes for the seventh entry in one of his series. This friend of Arnold Schoenberg emphasized the idea of “inner necessity” in his major theoretical work. The primitivist cover of a 1200 page leatherbound almanac was created by this friend of (*) Gabriele Münter. This synesthete author of Concerning the Spiritual in Art was long considered to have painted the first truly abstract painting. This artist’s musical approach to non-objective painting is exemplified by his series of Improvisations and Compositions. For 10 points, name this Russian founder of Der Blaue Reiter (“dare BLAO-uh RYE-tuh”).

Linolein containing multiple sites with this functional group is a major component of soybean oil. When treated with thiourea (“THIGH-oh-YOUR-ee-uh”), this functional group is converted to a thiirane (“THIGH-eye-rain”). This functional group can be formed by reacting a sulfonium ylide (“e-LIED”) with ketone or an  aldehyde in the Johnson-Corey-Chaykovsky reaction by a mechanism similar to (*) the Wittig (“VIH-tig”) reaction. Another method to synthesize this functional group is by reacting a peroxyacid such as mCPBA with an alkene. Opening these functional groups using either a base or an acid yields an alcohol, and they can be produced via an intermolecular Williamson synthesis. For 10 points, name these strained cyclic ethers whose namesake resins are found in adhesives.

This thinker noted that “in abolishing the true world we have also abolished the world of appearance,” in a short chapter of one of his books titled “How the ‘True World’ Became A Fable.” The confusion of cause and effect, false causality, imaginary causes, and free will are listed as the titular “Four Great Errors” in one section of a work by this philosopher. This thinker called (*) Goethe “the last German whom I respect,” and observed that philosophers have all come to the conclusion that life is worthless in a chapter on “The Problem of Socrates.” This philosopher expanded a chapter titled “Morality as the Enemy of Nature” into a thorough critique of Christianity which he included in a later work. For 10 points, identify this German philosopher who instructed on “How to philosophize with the hammer,” in his Twilight of the Idols.

An author with this first name wrote about an investigator who investigates the death of Ed Yellings, who finds a cure for heroin addiction. One character with this name sees Pip go mad after getting tangled in a line. Agha Shahid Ali quotes a saying about this name to end the ghazal “Tonight.” Black Herman and PaPa LaBas fight the Wallflower Order, who try to eradicate the Jes Grew dancing virus, in a novel by an author with this first name who wrote The Last Days of Louisiana Red. This is the first name of the author of (*) Mumbo Jumbo, whose last name is Reed. This is the name of a character who prevents himself from "methodically knocking people's hats off" “whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul” by going to sea, where he befriends the Polynesian Queequeg. For 10 points, Moby Dick begins with a man saying, "Call me" [this name].
tossups.answer: Ishmael [accept Ishmael Reed or “Call me Ishmael” or “Call me Ishmael tonight”]

tossups.question: A failed plan to revitalize this region’s shipbuilding industry led to the “Fast Ferry Scandal” during the premiership of Glen Clark. Phil Gaglardi spearheaded major highway expansion in this region in the cabinet of W. A. C. Bennett, who led a non-Albertan branch of the Social Credit Party to victory in seven consecutive elections. This region first became a colony after the Fraser Canyon Gold Rush, the year before a standoff over the San Juan Islands in which the only casualty was a (*) pig. This province became the sixth to join confederation after an agreement was signed to extend the Canadian Pacific Railway. This province which hosted Expo ‘86 invested in massive infrastructure projects like Skytrain and Canada Place. For 10 points, name this third-most populous province of Canada, home to Vancouver.

Hi’iaka (“HEE-ah-kuh”) brought back Pele (“PELL-ay”) by performing this action after the latter disappeared for nine days while trying to see Lohiau (“LOW-hee-uh”). Hephaestus made bronze statues called Celedones (“KELL-uh-don-eez”) which performed this action at the Temple of Apollo in Delphi. The Greek god of marriage had a name reflecting this action and was often associated with Ialemus (“EYE-leh-muss”), a different form of this action. Vainamoinen (“VIE-nuh-MOY-nen”) performs this action to construct a boat which he sails to Tuonela; at his birth, he is promised (*) Aino after defeating Joukahainen (“YOKE-uh-HIGH-nen”) in a contest about performing this action. The Scythians made a man talented at this action their king; that man who was blinded following a contest about performing this action was Thamyris. For 10 points, Odysseus puts wax in his ears to avoid the Sirens perform what melodic action often accompanied by the lyre?
tossups.answer: singing [prompt on answers related to music; do not accept answers about playing instruments]

tossups.question: In one work, one of these animals stands by a man hanging upside down from an oak tree during a boar fight. One of these animals sleeps with a young consumptive girl, and when that animal dies, the author hopes that some of the smaller angels tickled his ears. That one of these animals is “made with cotton, with no bones” and has eyes compared to “two black crystal scarabs.” One of these animals is called “son of my bowels, born in my very house, my children’s plaything, my wife’s joy” because it earns one man half his income. A (*) silver-colored one of these animals is in a Juan Ramón Jiménez novel named for this animal “y yo” (“ee yo”). One of these animals is stolen by Giles de Pasamonte and often walks next to the horse Rosinante. For 10 points, name these animals, which include the squire Sancho Panza’s Dapple in Don Quixote.

This effect is explained by a wave function which has the form of the product over (read slowly) “quantity z sub i minus z sub j raised to the power n,” times an exponential term, where n is an odd number. A simple derivation of this effect can be performed by writing the Hamiltonian as a harmonic oscillator with the energy levels separated by the cyclotron frequency. The Laughlin wave function predicts that the (*) filling factor in this effect can take on fractional values. This effect causes conductivity to take on discrete values as electrons are confined to Landau levels, and was discovered in 2D electron gases in the inversion layer of a MOSFET by Klaus von Klitzing. For 10 points, name this quantum mechanical analogue of an effect in which a magnetic field causes a voltage difference in a current-carrying material.
tossups.answer: integer quantum Hall effect [accept fractional quantum Hall effect before “Klaus”; prompt on Hall effect]

tossups.question: Fray Íñigo (“Fry EE-nyee-goh”) Abbad y Lasierra published a comprehensive history of this place in 1788 which includes the first written reference to the güiro (“gwee-roh”). The Spanish Crown offered free land to migrants who populated this place in the Royal Decree of Graces of 1815. Lola Rodríguez de Tió penned the lyrics to the future anthem of this place during the same year it was the site of the Grito de Lares uprising. To prove Spaniards were not gods, Diego Salcedo was drowned on this island on the orders of the cacique (“ka-SEE-kay”) Agüeybaná II (“ah-GOO-ay-baw-NAH the second”). It’s not (*) Hispaniola or Cuba, but the indigenous inhabitants of this place called it Borikén, and Juan Ponce de León fought a 1511 war against the Taíno here. The residents of this place lost their Spanish citizenship in the Foraker Act, signed two years after the 1898 Treaty of Paris. For 10 points, name this commonwealth territory, a Caribbean island won along with Cuba by the United States in the Spanish-American War.

A protocol named for these entities used for Ethernet networks prevents broadcast radiation by preventing the existence of Layer 2 paths. A parallelized algorithm used to find these entities has a runtime calculated using the inverse Ackermann function; that algorithm has an initial sort, followed by a loop in which the minimum element is removed. If Zorn’s lemma is assumed, then every infinite connected graph has one of these entities. For a complete graph with n labelled vertices, the number of these entities equals n to the power of n minus two according to (*) Cayley’s formula. Two greedy algorithms used to find these entities which run in big O of E log V time are Prim’s algorithm and its generalization, Kruskal’s algorithm. For 10 points, name these entities which cannot exist in a disconnected graph and are acyclic, complete, and span the entire vertex set.
tossups.answer: spanning tree [accept minimum spanning tree; prompt on “tree”]

tossups.question: A prince in this region became the monk Jijang and used his expanding kasaya sash to determine how much land he needed on Mount Jiuhua. A monk from this region incorporated t'i-yung theory of Essence-Function in his form of “interpreted Buddhism”.  The Tongdosa temple is located in this country, as is a spiritual movement whose founder is regarded as the spiritual successor to the messiah who came to Earth as the new Adam. The (*) Taego order of monks was founded in this region home to a church whose married members can undergo a blessing ceremony. A monk named Jinul founded the Jogye order of Buddhism in this region as part of its Seon school. Jajang helped incorporate Buddhism into the Silla kingdom in, for 10 points, what region where Sun Myung Moon founded the Unification Church?
tossups.answer: Korea [or South Korea; or North Korea; accept historical kingdoms like Joseon, Goryeo, and Silla kingdom before read]

tossups.question: Students held one of the first civil rights sit-ins in this city’s Read's Drug Store in 1955. The Rip Raps and Plug Uglies confronted Democrats in this city to help win the mayor’s office for the Know-Nothings in 1854. The Supreme Court ruled that the Bill of Rights did not apply to state governments in an 1833 suit brought against this city by wharf owner John (*) Barron. The 1904 Great Fire in this city destroyed the newspaper offices of its Herald, where its “sage” H.L. Mencken was a reporter. Union troops traveling through this city faced rioters on Pratt Street, and earlier an alleged assassination plot led Abraham Lincoln to travel secretly through this city. The rockets’ red glare illuminated this city’s Fort McHenry for Francis Scott Key during the War of 1812. For 10 points, name this largest city in Maryland.

The New York Times wrote that this author’s message matched Auden’s “we must love one another or die” in a review of one of her novels. That novel chronicles the lives of Gerald, who adopts a horde of feral children, and Emily, who has a beloved cat-like dog. That novel by this author was partially based on the author’s time living with the teenager Jenny Dicki. In another novel, this author wrote about the Communist Centre Union, led by (*) Alice Mellings, which sets off a car-bomb that kills one of its own members. The narrator of one of this author’s novels recounts the end of her love affair in a yellow one of the title objects, and excerpts from that narrator’s writings are interspersed among the frame story “Free Women.” For 10 points, name this British-Zimbabwean author of Memoirs of a Survivor, The Good Terrorist, and a novel about Anna Wulf, The Golden Notebook.

The second movement of this piece begins with a short brass fanfare in 4/4 but then switches to 7/4, with the chorus singing on the downbeats and the low strings playing short jabs on the off-beats. The first and final movements of this piece both end with the chorus resolving a stack of F-sharps and C-sharps to an F-major chord. The premiere of this piece was intended to include soloists from three different countries. However, Soviet authorities barred Galina Vishnevskaya from singing at the premiere, which also featured (*) Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau (“dee-skow”) and Peter Pears. In the last movement of this piece, the soprano and chorus sing the Latin text of the “Libera me” while the tenor and baritone sing the words of “Strange Meeting” in English. For 10 points, name this piece which combines the poetry of Wilfred Owen with the Catholic mass for the dead, by Benjamin Britten.

This ruler aimed to abolish a Barrier Treaty regulating the Scheldt River in a conflict in which the only shot fired hit a soup kettle aboard Le Louis. This leader’s predecessor was persuaded by Abraham Mendel-Theben to intervene in a blood libel case in the town of Orkuta. The Vonckist and Statist factions resisted religious reforms of this leader in the short-lived United States of Belgium during the Brabant Revolution. This ruler infamously fell into a swamp after a supposed dispute over (*) schnapps led his artillery to unknowingly fire on his own men at the Battle of Karansebes. Attempts by this ruler to annex Bavaria provoked the Treaty of Teschen and the creation of the Furstenbund by Frederick the Great. For ten points, name this enlightened Holy Roman Emperor and son of Maria Theresa who abolished serfdom.
tossups.answer: Joseph II of Austria [prompt on Joseph]

tossups.question: When covariance information such as consensus, distinctiveness, and consistency are all high, people are likely to perform the “situational” form of this process. Morris and Peng studied this process by analyzing coverage of the 1991 University of Iowa shooting by American and Chinese newspapers. To explain the tradeoffs inherent in engaging in this process, Harold Kelley invented the discounting principle. This process's group-serving type is a generalization of its self-serving type. In a study examining this process, subjects believed others who had been assigned to write (*) pro-Castro essays were in fact pro-Castro. An experiment in which students rated the intelligence of a questioner and answerer in a trivia game demonstrated this process's correspondence bias. For 10 points, name this process in which a person assigns the cause of another’s behavior, often marked by a namesake fundamental error.
tossups.answer: attribution [accept attribution bias or fundamental attribution error; accept word forms]

tossups.question: This author included a poem about a “thick-leaved, ambrosial” oak-tree near the site of where “the beetle boometh,” the “bee hummeth,” and the title character “low-lieth.” In another work, this author described “huge sponges of millennial growth and height” swelling above a creature who “hath...lain for ages” and who would “rise and on the surface die.” This author of “Claribel” described a character who was (*) “half sick of shadows” and who had her title carved into a shallow boat before “the broad stream bore her far away.” This author included “Lancelot and Elaine” and “Guinevere” in his collection of twelve narrative poems recounting the legend of King Arthur. For 10 points, name this poet of “Idylls of the King” and “The Lady of Shalott.”

One protein that regulates these phenomena unusually lacks helix 12, and instead contains a hydrophobic domain that binds to N-CoR, which then activates HDAC3. A serine to glycine 662 mutation in one protein that regulates these phenomena causes familial ASP. NPAS2 is a paralog of one protein that regulates these processes, which are also controlled by a pair of nuclear receptors called Rev-ErbA alpha and beta. In fruit flies, the degradation of TIM by CRY allows an external (*) stimulus called a “zeitgeber” to influence these phenomena. In humans, the suprachiasmatic (“SUE-pruh-KEY-as-matic”) nucleus periodically promotes the production of vasopressin and melatonin during this cycle. For 10 points, name these endogenous biological cycles with a 24-hour period.

A conductor from this country faced calls to resign from the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra in 2013 after he claimed that orchestras “react better” to male conductors. A different conductor from this country was music director of the London Symphony Orchestra from 2007 to 2017 and often conducts with a toothpick. A composer from this country wrote an opera in which Renata obsessively searches for her love Madiel and is sentenced to be burned at the stake. The composer of (*) The Fiery Angel and Love for Three Oranges was from this country, as was a composer who turned away from opera after he was attacked in the article “Muddle Instead of Music” for formalism and coarseness. For 10 points, name this home country of Sergei Prokofiev and Dmitri Shostakovich.
tossups.answer: Russia [accept Soviet Union or USSR] (Every person in this tossup was alive during either the formation or the fall of the Soviet Union; the conductors in the first two sentences are Vasily Petrenko and Valery Gergiev, respectively.)

bonuses.leadin: Sulfamic acid has been shown to primarily exist in this form when in a solid state, and ylides (“e-LIEDs”) are a subclass of these in which the charges are on adjacent atoms. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these molecules which have a net charge of zero, but contain multiple functional groups which carry fully separated positive or negative charges which cancel each other out.
The quintessential examples of a zwitterion are these biological monomers, the simplest of which is glycine. These monomers make up peptides and proteins.

N,N,N-trimethylglycine (“N-N-N-try-MEH-thil-GLY-seen”) is one of these compounds, defined as zwitterions where the cationic (“cat-eye-ON-ick”) group does not contain a hydrogen. These compounds were named after the sugar-producing plant from which that glycine derivative was isolated.

bonuses.leadin: One play in this movement features Ian raping Cate in an expensive hotel room before the room is suddenly bombed and the city turns into a war zone. For 10 points each:
answers: Britain [or the United Kingdom; or the UK]
parts: Name this theater movement of the 1990s and 2000s, which often aims to be vulgar and shocking. This movement includes Anthony Neilson, Mark Ravenhill, and Sarah Kane.
The in-yer-face theater movement largely springs from this country, which also gave birth to "angry young men" like Kingsley Amis in the 1950s.
This seminal play of the "angry young men" depicts the working-class Jimmy leaving his upper-class wife Alison for her friend Helena, before they reconcile by pretending to be "bears and squirrels."

bonuses.leadin: In the Eastern Orthodox Church, this sacrament is dispensed to the congregation by spooning wine-soaked bread into a participant’s mouth. For 10 points each,
answers: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints [or Mormonism or LDS]
parts: Name this sacrament in which a Christian congregation ingests wine and bread to commemorate Jesus’ Last Supper.
Communion is sometimes observed via this process, in which communicants dip a piece of bread into a chalice of wine and ingest the two together.
Members of this church consume water instead of wine for the sacrament. This church broadly prohibits its adherents from drinking any alcohol as dictated by the Word of Wisdom.

bonuses.leadin: Geoffrey Bardon encouraged the transition from sand painting to acrylics in a community from this country that produces “dot-and-circle” paintings. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country home to Emily Kngwarreye (“ING-wur-eye”) and a contemporary indigenous art movement that began at Papunya in this country’s Northern Territory.

This action titles many abstract paintings by Emily Kngwarreye, with many collected at the Aboriginal Gallery of [this action]. Her paintings may refer to a primordial period in Aboriginal myth named for this action.
Kngwarreye began her career creating textiles using this technique popular in Southeast Asia, which involves coating parts of the cloth with wax and dyeing them to create a negative image.

bonuses.leadin: In a legal case concerning this institution, Viscount Sankey developed the living tree constitutional doctrine. For 10 points each:
answers: Conservative Party of Canada [or Liberal-Conservative Party of Canada]
parts: Name this legislative house opposite the Canadian House of Commons for which women were deemed eligible appointees by the 1929 Persons Case.

Prior to the Persons case, this prime minister denied a request to appoint Emily Murphy to the Senate on the grounds that women were not “persons” according to the British North America Act. This prime minister faced riots over conscription during WWI.

Four months after the Persons Case, Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King appointed Cairene Wilson as Canada’s first female senator because Emily Murphy belonged to this party that rivaled King’s Liberals.

bonuses.leadin: A long stream of gas extends from these objects nearly halfway around the night sky, passing under the galactic south pole. For 10 points each:
answers: Magellanic Clouds [accept Large Magellanic Cloud AND Small Magellanic Cloud]
parts: Name this pair of irregular galaxies that, along with Andromeda, are the only galaxies visible to the naked eye.

This event in the Large Magellanic Cloud generated a flood of neutrinos, twenty-five of which were detected on Earth, providing data on the mass of neutrinos and the mechanism of the gravitational collapse which caused this event.

Alcock et. al. observed light from the Large Magellanic Cloud undergoing microlensing due to dark matter in this region of the Milky Way. This spherical region contains most of the galaxy’s globular clusters and dark matter.

bonuses.leadin: One poem by this author claims that “a miracle is a miracle...it overtakes us...unawares,” while in another Christ claims that “like a caravan of barges, / The centuries will come floating from the darkness.” For 10 points each:
answers: life [or “My Sister Life” or “Sestra moya zhizin”]
parts: Name this author, whose most famous poem describes “spring rain shattering itself like glass” and compares “the timetable on the Kamyshin line” to the Bible as “the carriage throws window-light over the steppe.”
Pasternak framed twenty-five poems including “Hamlet,” “Miracle,” and “The Garden of Gethsemane” as the works of this doctor, and placed them at the end of a novel titled for him.

One of Pasternak’s poems states that this thing is “overflowing today” - that poem called “My Sister” [this thing] titles one of his collections. “Hamlet” ends by saying that this thing “is not a walk across a field.”

bonuses.leadin: The title character of this piece is represented by a soaring theme on solo violin, while her husband’s gruff theme is played by the brass and hints at a whole-tone scale. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “symphonic suite” by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov, based on A Thousand and One Nights.

In “The Legend of the Kalendar Prince,” this instrument introduces the prince’s theme after the violin plays Scheherazade’s. This instrument also introduces the main theme of the “Berceuse” or “Lullaby” in Stravinsky’s Firebird.

This other composer’s Aladdin Suite originated as incidental music to a play based on A Thousand and One Nights. In this composer’s fourth symphony, two sets of timpani “attack” each other with dissonant tritones.

bonuses.leadin: This politician sponsored the final version of the Sixteenth Amendment. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Rhode Island Senator who sponsored a compromise tariff with Sereno Payne that split Taft’s Republican Party.

Aldrich toured Europe as the chair of the National Monetary Commission to investigate solutions to a panic brought on by the collapse of this bank. J.P. Morgan guided the response to the 1907 collapse of this trust.
The Aldrich Plan produced by the National Monetary Commission recommended a central banking system that was implemented as this institution, currently chaired by Jerome Powell.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about extensive-form games, for 10 points each:
answers: subgame perfect Nash equilibrium [or SPNE; or subgame perfect equilibrium; or SPE; prompt on equilibrium or Nash equilibrium or perfect Nash equilibrium]
parts: Extensive-form games allow for conditions that use this adjective or its opposite. "Information" described by this adjective applies when both players know every past event in a game, and "competition" described by this adjective is characterized by a homogeneous market of price-takers.
For a game with perfect information, this is the strategy profile in which all nodes are assigned actions that maximize a player’s payoff.
Deriving subgame perfect equilibria via sequential rationality is the best way to avoid a situation where an irrational player introduces a threat described by this adjective.

bonuses.leadin: This poem was originally a sonnet, but a line about “the iron and velvet bloom of heat” was deleted from after a line about “the cold splintering, breaking” in a house with “chronic angers.” For 10 points each:
answers: funeral [or burial; or wake; or obvious equivalents; prompt on death]
parts: Name this Robert Hayden poem about the speaker’s father, who woke up early to heat the home on a cold morning without ever being thanked. It asks “what did I know / of love’s austere and lonely offices?”
A woman enjoys “late coffee and oranges in a sunny chair” and the “complacencies of the peignoir” in “Sunday Morning,” a poem by this author of “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.”

Robert Hayden wrote about one of these events taking place for “the Queen of Sunday” at the “Broken Hearts and Gates-Ajar.” Wallace Stevens’ “The Emperor of Ice Cream” is about preparations for one of these events.

bonuses.leadin: These molecules bind to Sialyl-Lewis X tetrasaccharides with high affinity. For 10 points each:
answers: selectins [or CD62; or Cluster of Differentiation 62; prompt on lectin]
parts: Name these glycoproteins that help leukocytes “roll” on the surface of vascular wall during infection.

During inflammation, endothelial cells release storage granules called Weible-Palade bodies containing P-selectins and this other glycoprotein critical for hemostasis. Mutations in this molecule cause the most common form of inherited blood-clotting disorder.

Circulating tumor cells can recruit platelets, allowing them to bind to endothelial cell walls during this process where a cancer cell breaks away from the primary tumor and migrates to a secondary site.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher offered an eccentric reading of Being and Time which he summed up as “all constitution is institution,” and argued that Dasein refers to a common pattern in his 1982 paper, “Heidegger on being a person.” For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this American philosopher who taught at Pitt and Chicago and whose unfinished commentary on Heidegger is titled Dasein Disclosed.

Haugeland wrote a book titled for “the very idea” of this discipline and edited two volumes of papers titled Mind Design that collect work in the philosophy of this technical field. This field’s aim is to make machines that think like people.
In a paper in Mind Design II, this philosopher defended symbol systems against connectionism. This former Rutgers professor theorized a “language of thought” and wrote The Modularity of Mind.

bonuses.leadin: This emperor ordered a replica of Potala Palace to be built in his Chengde Mountain Resort and ordered the compilation of the Shamanic Code. For 10 points each:
answers: Qianlong Emperor [or Hongli or Prince Bao of the First Rank]
parts: Name this grandson of the Kangxi Emperor who exterminated the Dzungars and crushed other frontier states in his Ten Great Campaigns.

Rebels among these people like Emin Khoja requested the aid of the Qianlong Emperor against the Dzungar Khanate. Contemporary China has rounded up millions of members of this ethnic group in reeducation camps in their province of Xinjiang.

Near the end of the Qianlong Emperor’s reign, this revolt broke out in Sichuan province. The imperial favorite Heshen embezzled appropriations for putting down this revolt, which inspired a later uprising of the Eight Trigrams.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about depictions of the AIDS epidemic in popular media. For 10 points each:
parts: This musical drama film follows filmmaker Mark and his HIV-positive roommate Roger in their Bohemian life in the East Village. This film was adapted from a popular Broadway musical created by Jonathan Larson.

In Philadelphia, the Tom Hanks-played Andy Beckett sues his former employer for discrimination after he is fired due to his AIDS diagnosis. Andy grows closer to his initially homophobic lawyer Joe Miller, who is played by this actor.
In this movie, writer Ned Weeks starts an organization called Gay Men’s Health Crisis to increase awareness of AIDS within the gay community. This TV movie starred Mark Ruffalo and Matt Bomer.

bonuses.leadin: One project leader was inspired by the design of this work to create a line of prefabricated low-income housing. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this film series. Kanye West was later forced to shut down building the aforementioned dome-like houses, inspired by Tunisian desert housing which was used to represent Tatooine (“TAH-too-een”) in this film series.

The Jedi Academy Library was ripped off from the Long Room in the library of this country’s oldest college. Medieval monasteries located in this country include Clonmacnoise (“CLON-muck-NEE-shuh”) and Skellig Michael, where the Ahch-To (“OCK-TOE”) scenes in The Last Jedi were filmed.
This architect designed the UAE's RAK Convention Center, which looks suspiciously like the Death Star, as well as Casa de Musica, which looks like a Jawa sandcrawler. This man also wrote S, M, L, XL.

bonuses.leadin: During his namesake civil war, this man was defeated at the Battle of Ruspina by his former lieutenant Titus Labienus. For 10 points each:
answers: Cato the Younger [or Marcus Porcius Cato Uticensis; or clear equivalents to the junior Cato; prompt on Marcus Porcius Cato]
parts: Name this dictator whose defeat of the Optimates solidified his control over the Roman Republic after crossing the Rubicon River.

Julius Caesar decisively defeated the forces of Metellus Scipio and King Juba I of Numidia at this battle. During this battle, Caesar’s archers caused the Optimates’ war elephants to panic and trample their own men.

Following the Battle of Thapsus, this longtime opponent of Caesar disemboweled himself in Utica. With the support of Pompey, this famously incorruptible Optimate senator revoked Caesar’s proconsulate, prompting Caesar to cross the Rubicon.

bonuses.leadin: A short story by this author begins with a young boy asking his father what he has done to deserve to attend his first day of school. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of the short story “Half a Day,” which ends with the boy coming out of the school day to find that he is now old and the world has changed. This author also wrote a short story about police shooting people at a bus stop in “Under the Shelter.”
This novel by Mahfouz tells the story of the lives of the Kirshas, who own a cafe, a young woman named Hamida, and other residents of the titular street.
Mahfouz is the only Nobel prize winner from this Arabic-speaking country where his Cairo trilogy is set.

bonuses.leadin: After Anansi steals the land of one of these animals, it tricks him by betting that he cannot fill a hole in the ground with food, for which he will be given a robe made of flies and vines. For 10 points each:
answers: making cloth [accept weaving; prompt on descriptions like spinning thread]
parts: Identify these animals, one of which instructs humanity to pour boiled grain over their dead in order to resurrect them in a myth from the Margi people.

Similar to the aforementioned story of the Margi people is one from these people, in which Unkulunkulu (“unk-oo-lunk-OO-loo”) makes people mortal because a lizard delivered his message of mortality before a chameleon could announce immortality.
In Yoruba myth, Olorun used her chameleon Agemo to help her defeat Olokun in a contest involving this task. Arachne was turned into a spider for defeating Athena in a contest involving this task.

bonuses.leadin: These devices often use pressure-sensitive paint to allow for measurements over a wide area. For 10 points each:
answers: angle of attack [or AOA; or alpha; or angle of incidence]
parts: Name these large tubes used in aerodynamics research. In these tubes, air is blown past an object to predict how the object will fly.

Wind tunnel testing often measures the lift coefficient across different values of this angle. This angle is measured between a reference line on an airfoil and the relative velocity vector between the airfoil and the air.
The lift on an airfoil can be determined from the Kutta condition, which states that this quantity, symbolized gamma, will adjust in order to keep the rear stagnation point at the trailing edge.
